author: Shiv Sahay Singh
text:
Says he shudders to think about another five years of Trinamool Congress

It is essential to have an electoral understanding between the Congress and the Communist Party of India (Marxist) in West Bengal, veteran Communist leader Somnath Chatterjee said, adding he shuddered to think about another five years of the Trinamool Congress.

“There are two parties [the Congress and the CPI(M)] believing in parliamentary democracy and they have been trying to come together thinking if they can pool their resources the people will get a real alternative,” Mr. Chatterjee told The Hindu .

Mr. Chatterjee, who had represented the Bolpur and Jadavpur Lok Sabha seats in the State, said “this is the minimum that should be done by democratic forces including the Congress and the Left.”

“As a resident of West Bengal I am very keen that this understanding comes about,” the former Speaker of the Lok Sabha said.

Asked whether the ideological contradictions between the two parties could be circumvented for the alliance, Mr. Chatterjee said: “It is a question of pooling democratic resources in the State to fight against the anti-democratic approach of the State government.”

He said those following the developments in West Bengal were aware that there was “no chance of changing the approach of the ruling party and that there is a need to totally uproot it.”

He said an informal agreement — when the parties do not agree in Delhi but Alimudddin Street (CPI-M) headquarters) and Bidhan Bhavan (Bengal Congress headquarters) join forces — may be worked out. However, such an agreement might not be effective as a formal understanding, he added.
title: Somnath bats for CPI(M)-Congress alliance
